content:
thunderbird offers a preview page. That is the one that displays content without clicking the message to open in a larger view. If you click through messages by clicking the link in message list pane, you are in the preview screen. But I am assuming your question is on privacy. Some tips are here:

  1. to avoid sending return receipts, click settings>general and scroll down to the 'return receipts' button and set to not return them
  2. in settings>privacy&security, untick to allow remote content in messages (you can add exceptions for senders you trust)

Doing those two things helps prevent senders from being informed when you read a message.
creator: davidsk

content: If by preview, you mean the first few lines of a message without opening it, there is no such option in TB (or any other mail app). If you see any part of a message beyond the headers, the message has been opened to the same degree as if it has been deliberately 'opened'. The default privacy settings will block remote content, and TB doesn't run scripts in any opened message, so beside that you'll have to exercise your judgment as to whether the message is legitimate.
creator: sfhowes

content:
There is nothing in that log to indicate anything but a successful IMAP login followed by a timeout when the system is asked for mail.

My guess is you have a defective antivirus product.

If it was a router issue you would not authenticate. If it was an encryption TLS type issue, again you would not authenticate. The server is indication is has a "next mail" and provided the reference.

SO I am guessing the antivirus is intercepting the message and going off to la la land. So try disabling the mail scanner and see if that helps.
creator: MattAuSupport

content: The option has been moved to a submenu of Open in the message context menu (see picture).
creator: sfhowes

content:
In an ideal world the following is something you may expect:

If the email is just a one off email which you received, then there is no conversation, so the option does not exist. If you replied to an email such as the one below in the list (it has a 'replied' arrow icon on the left of the Subject) then you should find the 'Open message in converation' option also included in list. That option would display the selected email, any other email in that conversion incluuding the reply you sent.

If you used this view: View > Sort by > threaded

You can toggle threads on and off by clicking on the 'Toggle message threads' column header - it's the first column in the list and has the 'starred' column next to it. Any email that displays in a thread should offer the right click > Open > Open Message in Conversation'.

If you want to just open an email to read in a new tab rather than view in 'Message Pane', then double click on the email in list is quicker than using the right click > Open > Open Message in New Tab' A double click will use the setting you set up here:

  • Settings > General
  • scroll down to 'Reading & Display' section
  • 'Open new messages in:'
  • There are 3 options, the default is a new tab.

However, having said all that and it does work like that in most cases.... I have some new non threaded and not replied to emails that do offer the right click > Open > Open Message in Conversation'. - not expected!

I also have emails that are a reply to me, so I sent the original email and the reply back to me is the one which does not offer 'Open message in conversation'. So I'm not seeing the option if first email was actually created by me. Unfortunately, in 'Sent' folder of that pop account any email that does display that option, nothing opens in any tab. In my gmail imap 'Sent Mail' folder, the option if offered Open Message in Conversation' does display in a new tab, but sadly does not include the received email in Inbox. But do the same on the replied email in Inbox and it shows both the received mesage and the one I sent.

I'm also seeing the option offered when it's a new received email, so only one - not part of any conversation. It seems it's not perfect and has flaws. Looks like there is some reason to suspect a bug of some type, but it might be helpful if I can narrow down the cause.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Thunderbird è un software gratuito per cui non esiste un supporto tecnico i cui costi sarebbero insostenibili. Questo è solo un forum di utenti volontari, chi vi partecipa lo fa con i tempi e modi che preferisce. Questo per dirti che arrivare qui, protendere riscontri urgenti e minacciare di cambiare software è del tutto surreale. Che tu usi o meno Thunderbird non cambia nulla per nessuno (se non per te stesso).

Seconda osservazione: probabile che tu sia abituato ad ecosistemi come quelli di Google, Apple e Microsoft dove la tua attività è strettamente monitorata e profilata. Ma Thunderbird non funziona così. Il programma opera completamente sotto il tuo controllo e tutti i suoi dati restano sul tuo PC. In altre parole se vuoi che qualcuno provi a darti una mano su questo forum devi riportare il maggior numero di dettagli possibili a cominciare dai messaggi di errore che ricevi quando provi a scaricare la posta con Thunderbird. Dire semplicemente che "non scarica la posta" è del tutto inutile proprio perché Thunderbird non è un servizio centralizzato ed il problema non è generale.

content:
This usually indicates a corrupted install. Try these steps:

  1. do NOT uninstall, as that may delete your message folders
  2. locate the program, either at c:\program files or c:\program files (x86) and delete it
  3. download and install your preferred version. I recommend ver 128, but it's your call.
  4. if you receive a compatibility error, locate the profile and delete a file named compatibility.ini (profile will be at c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird\profiless

content:
There is a Help article on this: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/moving-thunderbird-data-to-a-new-computer

I'll also add my method: 1. First make sure you have the same version of Thunderbird installed on both computers. On new computer - install Thunderbird and run - it will ask for Mail accounts - but you want to get all data from old computer so do not bother and exit Thunderbird.

I'm assuming you are using a Windows OS and all profile data is in the default location.

2. Exit Thunderbird - it's important that on both computers Thunderbird is not running - so close.

On Old Computer:

  1. In window search type: %Appdata% - see image below as guide
  2. Select the %Appdata% file folder
  3. select 'Roaming'
  4. Copy the 'Thunderbird' folder to an external drive

On NEW Computer:

  1. In window search type: %Appdata% - see image below as guide
  2. Select the %Appdata% file folder
  3. select 'Roaming'
  4. Delete the default 'Thunderbird' folder
  5. Paste the copied 'Thunderbird' folder into the 'Roaming Folder'

Start Thunderbird.
creator: Toad-Hall
